SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

Abstract of explanation to the person answering this Questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences as an older person. If possible for you to answer, so do not worry about leaving blank spaces. If you have trouble answering any question, try to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Western Canadian Pioneers' Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer List: What Did You Answer This?" and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All Questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Retention of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's collection at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of the Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. A brief explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as anyone else. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so do not worry about having blank spaces. If you have any stories or tales of pioneer life to tell, please put them down. If you have any personal experiences to relate, please put them down.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether they now live in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

B. Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer List: What Did Western Canadian History Entail?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this list and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian History Entail?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this list and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

C. All Questionnaires

( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

D. Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

In 1902 my father took a second homestead in the Creelman district. Here I met & late married my husband & we build upon there farm.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

1. Sang & taught
2. Became a farmer's wife

She was very economically resourceful.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

In 1902 my father took a second homestead in the Creelman district. Here I met my late husband and we built up our home here.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

My husband's health failed. We returned here & he died in 1924. We left to raise 5 children on the farm which I did successfully.

1. Taught school.
2. Became a farmer's wife.

[Handwritten note:]
She was more economically secure.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Robert J. Mott. We married in Regina July 1st, 1912

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

No

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Three in Manitoba

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Yes we traveled about with fast horses a great deal. The cultivated area was smaller so people had more time to travel about - to church to Regina - to Morse Mines for wood, fruit to the lakes for fish, to hunt deer, goose ducks for uncounted picnics & community gatherings. In the winter we attended social gatherings at school once a week - in the school - in the homes. There was more community sociability than now.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, who?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience or pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Yes we travelled about with foot horses a great deal. The cultivated area was small so people had some time to travel about - hitched to Reina - to go see folks, to work, hunt, to the lake to fish, to hunt deer, game ducks, for uncounted picnics - community gatherings. In the winter we attended annual gatherings at each end of the ranch in the homestead.

She was hard working, economical, hardworking, hardworking, hardworking.
25. When was the first car used in the community? Around 1910

26. If you owned a car before 1911, when did you buy it? What make? Ford in 1916

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your house? Creelman - 7 miles of the N.W. came in 1904, before that W. Valdina

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Once a month

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? 1905

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

Mail buying has greatly increased since then as butter, eggs were bartered for newspapers, cash was paid

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? Creelman Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? Yes

26. If you owned a car before 1914, then did you buy it? How much?

1906 - Clothing Mail buying has greatly increased since then as bulky egg were bought for purchase and storage.

1908

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to this settlement the first time was it with the idea of settling permanently? Or did you make up your mind after living here? What did you make while you lived here?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
Yes, they proved up on their homesteads and moved on to more exciting pastures as life here became more hum-drum.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
Some moved away & about as many returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
We always have been community builders & took active part in all undertakings except the C.C.H.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
We were charter members of church, grain growers, telephone co., exhibition board here - council etc. My father bid in the first buggy to the first piano by wagon across from our chapel.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
1903 School district - Cruff - from Cruff in town where father was born.
1903 Creelman town - from Mr. Creelman official of C.P.R.
No change ever made.
1905 Sequin S.D. - from the Sequin, a boat on Lake Huron. Mr. Briggs gave it.

Briggs, Emma Regina.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? Yes, they moved up on their homesteads—moved on to more exciting pastures.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Some moved away—about as many relocated.
